elements.title: Protection Shield Visual Language — Trust Iconography System
elements.problem: The 24-hour protection model, security deposit held by SplitLease, and refund guarantee are the most persuasive trust signals in the guest journey (Theodore's entire call turned on these). But there's no visual language for financial protection. Trust signals compete with pricing, listing details, and photos for visual attention. Greever notes that 'being articulate imparts intelligence' — the visual treatment of protection must feel authoritative, not decorative.
elements.solution: Create a 'Protection Shield' visual system: (1) A shield icon with 3 horizontal stripes (one per protection layer) in gradient purple. (2) Place it on a subtle off-white background (--bg-off-white) with a thin purple border. (3) Use DM Sans semibold for the protection labels — slightly softer than Inter to convey care rather than corporate authority. (4) Each protection point gets a checkmark icon in secondary purple. The visual weight should be equivalent to the price display — protection and price are co-primary.

evidence.quote: We hold the payment until you spend at least 24 hours in the property to make sure that the property corresponds exactly to what was advertised.
evidence.insight: The protection model resolved Theodore's commitment anxiety. The visual treatment must convey the same authority and completeness.

evidence.quote: Imparts intelligence... Demonstrates intentionality... Expresses confidence... Shows respect.
evidence.insight: Greever's four qualities of articulate design apply directly to visual trust signals — they must look intelligent, intentional, confident, and respectful.

new_tokens_needed: --shield-icon-gradient: linear-gradient(135deg, #31135D 0%, rgb(109, 49, 194) 100%) — for the protection shield icon fill

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Protection labels (#31135D on #FCFAFF) = 12.8:1 — exceeds AA. Check icons (secondary purple on off-white) must be at least 3:1 for non-text elements.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Protection Shield has equal visual weight to price display. Both use bold/semibold, both get dedicated visual containers. Protection appears ABOVE or BESIDE the price, never below.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste model's 'Trustworthy, not corporate' principle. DM Sans softens the authority without reducing it. Purple gradient shield connects protection to the brand palette.

elements.title: Articulation Microcopy Typography — Conversational Explanations at Decision Points
elements.problem: The UI currently presents information in two modes: headlines (big, bold) and body text (small, gray). But articulation microcopy — the conversational 'why this works this way' explanations — doesn't fit either mode. It needs to feel like the agent speaking, not like documentation or marketing. Greever distinguishes between 'what the design does' and 'why it's the right choice' — these require different visual treatments.
elements.solution: Create a distinct visual treatment for articulation microcopy: (1) Use a subtle background tint (--bg-off-white or rgba(49,19,93,0.04)) to visually separate it from standard content. (2) Set in Inter 400, 13px, --text-description (#374151) — conversational weight, not instructional. (3) Maximum 2 lines. (4) Preceded by a small icon (info-circle or lightbulb in --text-light-gray). (5) Rounded corners (--rounded-lg, 8px) on the background container. This creates a 'quiet voice' that the eye can find when needed but doesn't compete with primary content.

evidence.quote: The agent's tone throughout: conversational, reassuring, not lecturing. 'I'm pretty sure I would be able to help you out' (14:09).
evidence.insight: The agent's voice is the model for articulation microcopy: confident, casual, brief. Not formal, not legal, not marketing.

evidence.quote: Establish a Positive Persona... Change Your Vocabulary.
evidence.insight: Greever says the communicator's persona matters as much as the content. Articulation microcopy must feel like a knowledgeable friend, not a manual.

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. #374151 on rgb(252,250,255) = approximately 9.5:1 — exceeds AA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Articulation microcopy is a SUPPORT tier — visually present but not competing with headlines or CTAs. The background tint makes it findable; the small font size makes it unobtrusive.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste model's 'Confident, not flashy' — the microcopy doesn't shout; it's there when needed. 'Human language, real data' — conversational tone matches the agent's voice.

elements.title: Matching Pipeline Visualization — Progress Through Stages
elements.problem: During the 2-3 week matching period, the guest has no visual representation of progress. Timeline or pipeline visualizations in the current design system are limited to the between-stay timeline (ds-ui-1000-004). The matching process needs its own visual language that communicates stages, current position, and expected duration without looking like a shipping tracker or a loading bar.
elements.solution: Create a horizontal pipeline visualization using connected nodes: (1) Each stage is a circle (28px) connected by a thin line (2px, --border-color). (2) Completed stages: filled purple (--secondary-purple), checkmark icon in white. (3) Current stage: outlined purple (--secondary-purple border, white fill), pulsing subtle animation. (4) Future stages: filled --bg-light-gray, no icon. (5) Below each node: stage label (Inter, 500, 11px, --text-gray). (6) Below current stage: estimated time (Inter, 400, 11px, --secondary-purple). The horizontal layout implies forward progress; the pulsing current node implies active work.

evidence.quote: Give us two to three weeks... all the bids submitted on one week goes through the matching process next week.
evidence.insight: The matching process has real stages (submission → batch review → host matching → introduction) that can be visualized as a pipeline.

evidence.quote: From IDEA to IDEAL... Putting It All Together.
evidence.insight: Greever's progression model (present, discuss, refine, agree) maps to the matching pipeline. The visual must show the guest that progress is a journey with known stages.

new_tokens_needed: --animation-pulse: subtle opacity pulse 0.8-1.0 at 2s interval — for current pipeline stage

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. Purple nodes on white background: sufficient. Labels (#6b7280 on #fff) = 4.6:1 — meets AA for small text.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Pipeline sits at SECONDARY tier on the matching status page. Current stage has the most visual weight (outline + pulse). Total pipeline width should not exceed 400px to prevent overwhelming the guest.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste model's 'Fast response, gentle settle' animation philosophy. The pulse is subtle (opacity, not size or position), conveying 'work in progress' without anxiety.

elements.title: Reframing Comparison Cards — Side-by-Side Familiar vs. New
elements.problem: Theodore's mental model was shaped by Airbnb. The agent's most effective technique was reframing by comparison ('does anyone come to see your Airbnb?'). Visually, the platform has no pattern for showing side-by-side comparisons that help guests reframe their expectations. Existing card patterns are for content display, not conceptual reframing.
elements.solution: Create a 2-column comparison card pattern: (1) Left column labeled 'What you might expect' (--bg-light-gray background, --text-gray text). (2) Right column labeled 'How SplitLease works' (--bg-off-white background, --primary-purple text). (3) Each row shows one concern with a crossed-out misconception on the left and the reality on the right. (4) Right column gets a subtle purple left-border (3px, --secondary-purple) per existing actionable-card pattern. (5) Max 3 rows per comparison card. The visual asymmetry (gray left, purple-tinted right) guides the eye toward the SplitLease approach.

evidence.quote: When you rent your apartment over Airbnb, does anybody come to see your apartment?
evidence.insight: The comparison resolved the objection instantly. The visual pattern must achieve the same reframing effect.

evidence.quote: Why is it better than the alternative?
evidence.insight: Greever's third question for every design decision. Comparison cards answer this visually.

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. All text colors meet minimum contrast on their respective backgrounds.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Right column (SplitLease approach) has stronger visual weight through tint + purple accent. Left column is intentionally muted to guide the eye toward the reframe.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste model's 'Premium-accessible' — the comparison doesn't attack competitors, it elevates SplitLease through contrast.
